Alabama vs Michigan.title: Michigan holds off Alabama in 2024 ReliaQuest Bowl as sloppy performance dooms Jalen Milroe, Crimson Tide - CBSSports.com
Alabama vs Michigan.content: If not listed, please contact your TV provider. Michigan earned a huge 19-13 win against No. 11 Alabama in the ReliaQuest Bowl on Tuesday. The shorthanded Wolverines, who were down several key players due to both opt outs and the transfer portal, led wire-to-wire after taking advantage of numerous Alabama mistakes in the first quarter. The Crimson Tide turned the ball over three times -- and had their first offensive drive end with a failed fourth-down conversion -- in the first 15 minutes. That means for its first four possessions Michigan's average starting position was Alabama's 21-yard line. The Wolverines took advantage, even if they left some points on the board. Three of Michigan's first four drives ended in a field goal from kicker Dominic Zvada, two of which came from 30 yards or less. Quarterback Davis Warren, who later exited the game with an apparent leg injury, did hit wide receiver Fredrick Moore for a 13-yard touchdown and Michigan left the first quarter with a 16-0 lead it never surrendered. Alabama had 2 total yards of offense until late in the second quarter when it went on two drives that covered a combined 161 yards and resulted in 10 points. It wasn't enough to spark a full comeback, however. The Crimson Tide actually had a chance to win it late in the fourth quarter. One possession after kicker Graham Nicholson hit a season-long 51-yard field goal which cut Michigan's lead to one possession, Alabama got the ball all the way to Michigan's 15-yard line. But on fourth-and-10, Milroe came under immediate pressure and threw an incomplete pass, which allowed Michigan to take possession and kneel the clock out on a momentum-building bowl victory. That was a common theme for the Wolverines through 2024, especially in their last two wins against Ohio State and Alabama. Michigan didn't play a great game on offense. In fact, after the first quarter, it was largely ineffective. But it did do enough to put the game away. Michigan's shorthanded defense definitely deserves a ton of credit, as the Wolverines held Alabama scoreless for almost three entire quarters, which allowed the offense to sit on their early 16-0 lead. Michigan did employ a smart ball-control strategy to limit Alabama's possessions and, thus, its explosive potential on offense. The Wolverines gained just 32 yards in the third quarter, but they held onto the football for a whopping 10:52 seconds. That took the air out of Alabama's late first-half surge, when it scored 10 unanswered points to cut Michigan's lead to 16-10. Michigan won the time of possession battle by almost 17 minutes, with a lot of its advantage created in that third quarter. That kept the defense fresh and it limited Alabama's window to mount a comeback. Michigan's modern run of success has been keyed, largely, by excellent running back play. The Wolverines have had star players like Blake Corum, Donovan Edwards and Kalel Mullings lead their offense while gashing opposing defenses on the ground. They may have found the next great one in freshman running back Jordan Marshall. Marshall was thrust into a starting role after Mullings and Edwards opted out and he responded with a strong performance, especially after Michigan lost starting quarterback Davis Warren to injury. Marshall carried the ball 23 times for 100 yards, averaging just over four yards per carry against a strong Alabama defense. He had a key 24-yard run early in the fourth quarter, bouncing off of Alabama defenders in the process, to set up Dominic Zvada's decisive 37-yard field goal. Not bad for a true freshman making his first career start. Marshall certainly provided Michigan fans with some optimism about the future of the Wolverines' offense, especially with players like five-star quarterback Bryce Underwood joining the fold moving forward. Alabama quarterback Jalen Milroe still has yet to make a decision on his future. Before Tuesday's bowl game, he was considered an intriguing NFL Draft prospect with plenty of untapped upside and physical traits that would make him a desirable option for front offices, likely in the middle rounds. Now his stock is up in the air. Milroe definitely had his moments in the ReliaQuest Bowl. He had one 41-yard run where he flashed his athleticism and weaved around Michigan defenders to set up Alabama's second scoring drive. He had nice throws of 25 yards to tight end Robbie Ouzts for Alabama's first touchdown of the game, and a deep 40-yard completion to wide receiver Germie Bernard near the end of the second quarter. But, overall, he was largely ineffective. He turned the ball over three times in the first quarter alone. One of those was on a botched snap, and the other was an interception after he mistimed a shallow out route. Milroe also had multiple misses on passes at every level of the field. His pocket awareness was concerning, as he struggled to sense pressure and often held onto the ball for too long. There's a good chance that Milroe still gets drafted if he declares, especially since he's one of the most physically gifted quarterbacks in college football. His lackluster bowl performance left a sour last impression on scouts, though. Or, at the very least, take a late lead. Michigan was gifted a first down thanks to an unsportsmanlike conduct penalty on Alabama linebacker Justin Jefferson, but the Wolverines weren't able to do much more with the free yardage. The Crimson Tide defense, which has been great all day, forced a punt that Alabama's Ryan Williams returned 38 yards to give his team possession on Alabama's 44-yard line. Prime scoring opportunity, though the Tide need a touchdown at this point. We've got some clutch kicking in the ReliaQuest Bowl. Alabama stalled at Michigan's 33-yard line during a crucial drive. Instead of going for it on fourth-and-10, the Crimson Tide sent kicker Graham Nicholson out. He hit his second field goal of the day and set his season high with a 51-yard boot. It had enough power behind it to split the uprights from even further out. Alabama's hanging around. Dominic Zvada, still one of the most important players in college football. It's rare that a college kicker is so reliable, but he has now hit on all four of his field goal attempts in the ReliaQuest Bowl. His latest, from 37 yards out, was the biggest, as it expanded Michigan's lead back to two possessions with 7:21 left to play. Michigan leaned on running back Jordan Marshall, who carried the ball five times, to get into scoring range. He had a nice 24-yard run that moved the ball into Alabama territory. Alabama, which has scoring drives of 71 and 90 yards, was unable to capitalize on its best starting field position of the game after a Zabien Brown interception handed Alabama the ball on the 50-yard line. Alabama quarterback Jalen Milroe almost threw an interception on third-and-7. The Crimson Tide still went for it, and Milroe was late on a pass to Jaylen Mbakwe, who caught the ball out of bounds. Michigan stills holds a narrow lead after three quarters of play. Five drives ended without any points in the third quarter. Four of those resulted in punts, while the fifth was cut short when Michigan quarterback Alex Orji threw an interception to Alabama defensive back Zabien Brown. The biggest news coming out of the third quarter was the fact that Michigan starting quarterback Davis Warren was taken to the locker room with an apparent leg injury. Without Warren, the Wolverines turned to Orji, who hasn't been able to make anything happen on offense. Alabama will start the fourth quarter with a prime opportunity to finally jump into the lead. Brown's interception gave the Tide the ball at the 50-yard line, and a quick 9-yard completion to wide receiver Rico Scott put Alabama in Michigan territory for the first time since the second quarter ended. All 16 of Michigan's points thus far came in the first quarter. Not counting the end of the first half, the Wolverines have punted on five consecutive drives since. They have crossed midfield just once since the first quarter and all four of their first-quarter drives began in plus territory. So that means Michigan's offense has possessed the ball 10 times, but it has made it past the 50-yard line just once. The Wolverines still have yet to gain more than 34 yards in a single drive. Now Alabama is having injury issues of its own. Top linebacker Jihaad Campbell just left the field with an apparent injury after attempting a tackle on Michigan running back Jordan Marshall. He was slow to get up and didn't walk off the field until Alabama's training staff came out to help him. He would be a huge loss fro the Crimson Tide defense, which has played very well today. Michigan's offense is still spinning its wheels after an ineffective drive to open the second half. To make matters worse, starting quarterback Davis Warren appears injured after taking a long sack. Alabama defensive linemen dragged Warren down near the sideline and Warren remained on the turf for a few moments. He initially got up, with the help of teammates, but went back to the ground after taking a few steps. Warren wasn't putting much weight on his right leg, which got bent under him when Smith brough him to the ground. Michigan leads No. 11 Alabama 16-7 at halftime of the ReliaQuest Bowl after the first two quarters felt way more lopsided than the score may indicate. Alabama turned the ball over three times in the first quarter -- and that doesn't include its first drive, which ended in a failed fourth-down conversion -- which gave Michigan three drives that started in the red zone. In spite of that, the Wolverines only found the end zone once in the first half thanks to a 13-yard connection between quarterback Davis Warren and wide receiver Fredrick Moore. Moore, who stepped into a bigger role when Michigan lost its top two receivers entering Tuesday's game, had a nice first half with three catches for 37 yards and the score. Though it took Alabama's offense a long time to find its footing, Michigan's inability to fully capitalize on Alabama's numerous mistakes allowed the Crimson Tide to keep the door open. They captured some late momentum with a four-play, 71-yard drive capped by a 25-yard touchdown connection between quarterback Jalen Milroe and tight end Robbie Ouzts near the end of the second quarter. Prior to that 71-yard scoring drive, Alabama had 2 total yards on offense. The Crimson Tide now enter halftime outgaining Michigan by 54 yards. Michigan's offense needs to figure something out in the second half. The Wolverines, who will receive the kickoff, cannot sit on their lead with Alabama's offense starting to hit its stride. It seemed like Alabama would have been content to run the clock out and enter half time when it gained possession at its own 4-yard line with just 50 seconds left to play and no timeouts. But, on third-and-1, Michigan inexplicably saved some clock for the Crimson Tide by calling a timeout. Then quarterback Jalen Milroe ripped off a 41-yard run, and hit wide receiver Germie Bernard for a gain of 40 yards, which put the Crimson Tide in prime scoring position. Kicker Graham Nicholson eventually ate into Michigan's lead with a 24-yard field goal. It took over 25 minutes, but Alabama's offense finally looks like itself. The Crimson Tide just battled back into this game with an easy 71-yard drive, marching down the field in just four plays to score their first touchdown of the game. Freshman wide receiver Rico Scott got things started with a 28-yard gain on a jet sweep play. Alabama then gained a combined 15 yards on a tight end screen that Josh Cuevas fumbled. Offensive lineman Elijah Pritchett recovered the ball and rumbled for another eight yards. Then, a couple plays later, Alabama quarterback Jalen Milroe hit a wide open Robbie Ouzts for a 25-yard touchdown. The only positive thing to say for Alabama's offense thus far is that it has now gone two straight possessions without a turnover. Both of those drives still ended in a punt, though. The Crimson Tide have more turnovers (3) than total yards (2). Their offense totals are being dragged down by their minus 16 yards rushing. Alabama quarterback Jalen Milroe has already been sacked three times, and Alabama's running backs have combined for 11 yards on five carries. Milroe, who was responsible for all three turnovers, is having a rough game. Outside of the mistakes, he's also been inaccurate passing the ball thus far and had a couple misses on Alabama's latest drive that forced it into another punt. Alabama's defense has played well thus far, and it just got a much-needed stop after the Crimson Tide punted for the first time. Michigan gained 24 yards in eight plays and took five minutes off the clock but, ultimately, had to punt short of the 50-yard line after a rush attempt was stoned on third-and-8. Alabama returner Ryan Williams decided to field the punt at Alabama's 16-yard line and was tackled immediately, which means that the Crimson Tide will, once again, start with unfavorable field position. The ReliaQuest Bowl really couldn't be going much worse for Alabama thus far. The Crimson Tide turned the ball over three times and had another drive end with a failed fourth-down conversion in the first quarter. One of those turnovers was an entirely unforced error when quarterback Jalen Milroe fumbled the ball on a botched snap exchange. That was the first of two fumbles for Milroe, who also had an interception. Even with all of that, Michigan wasn't able to exit the first quarter with a completely decisive lead. All four of Michigan's drives started in Alabama territory with the average start at Alabama's 21-yard line, but Michigan still came out with three field goals courtesy of kicker Dominic Zvada. Alabama's defense is keeping the Tide in this game and covering for an offense that, in addition to its sloppy play, finished the first frame with minus-2 total net yards. Credit Alabama's defense for keeping this game from spiraling entirely out of control. Michigan gained possession inside Alabama's 10-yard line after a strip-sack of Alabama quarterback Jalen Milroe but the Wolverines were unable to score a touchdown with more advantageous field position. Instead, Michigan kicker Dominic Zvada made his third field goal of the game, this one a kick from 21 yards out. Four plays and three turnovers now for Alabama. This time, quarterback Jalen Milroe came under pressure off the edge when dropping back to pass on first-and-10. Cornerback Amir Hall, who came through on a blitz, got a hand on Milroe's arm and forced the ball loose. Michigan defensive lineman Cameron Brandt was able to recover the fumble and stumbled for a gain of five yards. Now a third straight possession that will start in the red zone for the Wolverines. Michigan finally took full advantage of another Alabama mistake. After kicking field goals on Alabama's first two turnovers -- a failed fourth-down conversion and a fumble -- the Wolverines got the ball in the red zone again thanks to an interception from defensive back Wesley Walker. On third-and-7, quarterback Davis Warren lofted a pass to wide receiver Fredrick Moore, who made a phenomenal toe-tapping catch to secure a 13-yard touchdown. About everything that could go wrong for Alabama thus far has. All three of the Crimson Tide's offensive drives have now ended in a turnover. Quarterback Jalen Milroe just threw a bad interception where he stared down a receiver on an out route and pulled the trigger too late, allowing Michigan defensive back Wesley Walker to hop the route and tip the ball to himself for an interception. This is Michigan's second straight drive that will start in the red zone. Two drives that started with favorable field position and two field goals for Michigan thus far. The Wolverines got the ball in the red zone after Alabama fumbled a snap due to the bad weather. They weren't able to get a ton of yardage with three straight runs and settled for the points with a 30-yard field goal from kicker Dominic Zvada. A smart strategy in a game that may not see a ton of offense due to the conditions. It's absolutely pouring in Tampa Bay. It didn't take long to negatively affect Alabama. On the first play of the Crimson Tide's second drive, Alabama snapped the ball in shotgun formation. Quarterback Jalen Milroe couldn't get a good handle on the wet ball and fumbled it. The loose ball bounced around a bit before ending up in the hands of Michigan's Derrick Moore, who already had a big sack that ended Alabama's first offensive drive. Michigan's defense gave its offense favorable field position with a big sack and the Wolverines were able to capitalize. It didn't take much effort to get into field goal range, given Dominic Zvada's leg, and Michigan did just enough to attempt a 45-yard kick that Zvada nailed in the pouring rain. He's been Michigan's offensive MVP all year and he'll be crucial in what's shaping up to be a very bad weather game. Alabama worked the ball just past the 50-yard line and decided to go for it on fourth-and-4, looking to put some points on the board early. But Michigan's defense, which is going to have to have a big game to keep this one close, was up to the task. Crimson Tide quarterback Jalen Milroe dropped back to pass and immediately came under pressure from Michigan edge rusher Derrick Moore, who bullied the right tackle and sacked Milroe for a big loss. Michigan takes over in Alabama territory, on the edge of kicker Dominic Zvada's field goal range. Michigan won the opening toss and deferred to the second half, which means that Alabama's offense will start with the ball. The Crimson Tide have a good chance to set the tone early against a shorthanded Michigan defense, given that Kalen DeBoer's squad is almost at full strength. That includes quarterback Jalen Milroe, who has yet to make a final NFL Draft decision and, as such, is playing in Tuesday's bowl game. Games between big-time programs are sometimes as simple as effort and participation. Expect that to take center stage. Alabama has a strong culture of showing up for bowl games, winning eight of their last nine -- all except the Rose Bowl against Michigan last season. Don't expect the Tide to waste the opportunity, especially with a chance to reach 10 wins. Pick: Alabama -10.5 Michigan has already secured at least one transfer portal win over Alabama. The Wolverines signed former Crimson Tide defensive lineman Damon Payne, who is a three star in 247Sports' Transfer Rankings. He, obviously, cannot play in the ReliaQuest Bowl, but he is a big add for Michigan's future. Michigan is also the presumed favorite for Alabama transfer running back Justice Haynes, the No. 1 running back in the portal. Haynes has already received two 247Sports Crystal Ball predictions to land at Michigan. He'd be a clear starter in a room that, as outlined below, looks a little depleted entering the 2025 season. Not counting its transfer portal departures, Alabama is expected to be at mostly full strength. Coach Kalen DeBoer said during the head coaches press conference Monday that he hasn't had conversations with any of Alabama's players about opting out. That includes quarterback Jalen Milroe, who is still mulling over his NFL Draft decision. "I'd be pretty surprised," DeBoer said of any opt outs. "I think they're here to win. To compete. To put the best product we can put out there on the football field for four quarters and go out there. I wouldn't expect something like that." Michigan running back Kalel Mullings will not play in the ReliaQuest Bowl as he prepares for the 2025 NFL Draft. Mullings, a former linebacker, had the best season of his college career in 2024, rushing for a team-high 948 yards and 12 touchdowns. Mullings entered the season as the backup behind Donovan Edwards and assumed the role as the Wolverines' bellcow running back just weeks into the season. Edwards also opted out, which leaves the Wolverines short on experienced running backs as they prepare for their showdown against Alabama. Cornerback Amir Hall, who came through on a blitz, got a hand on Milroe's arm and forced the ball loose. Michigan defensive lineman Cameron Brandt was able to recover the fumble and stumbled for a gain of five yards. Now a third straight possession that will start in the red zone for the Wolverines. Michigan finally took full advantage of another Alabama mistake. After kicking field goals on Alabama's first two turnovers -- a failed fourth-down conversion and a fumble -- the Wolverines got the ball in the red zone again thanks to an interception from defensive back Wesley Walker. On third-and-7, quarterback Davis Warren lofted a pass to wide receiver Fredrick Moore, who made a phenomenal toe-tapping catch to secure a 13-yard touchdown. About everything that could go wrong for Alabama thus far has. All three of the Crimson Tide's offensive drives have now ended in a turnover. Quarterback Jalen Milroe just threw a bad interception where he stared down a receiver on an out route and pulled the trigger too late, allowing Michigan defensive back Wesley Walker to hop the route and tip the ball to himself for an interception. This is Michigan's second straight drive that will start in the red zone. Two drives that started with favorable field position and two field goals for Michigan thus far. The Wolverines got the ball in the red zone after Alabama fumbled a snap due to the bad weather. They weren't able to get a ton of yardage with three straight runs and settled for the points with a 30-yard field goal from kicker Dominic Zvada. A smart strategy in a game that may not see a ton of offense due to the conditions. It's absolutely pouring in Tampa Bay. It didn't take long to negatively affect Alabama. On the first play of the Crimson Tide's second drive, Alabama snapped the ball in shotgun formation. Quarterback Jalen Milroe couldn't get a good handle on the wet ball and fumbled it. The loose ball bounced around a bit before ending up in the hands of Michigan's Derrick Moore, who already had a big sack that ended Alabama's first offensive drive. Michigan's defense gave its offense favorable field position with a big sack and the Wolverines were able to capitalize. It didn't take much effort to get into field goal range, given Dominic Zvada's leg, and Michigan did just enough to attempt a 45-yard kick that Zvada nailed in the pouring rain. He's been Michigan's offensive MVP all year and he'll be crucial in what's shaping up to be a very bad weather game. Alabama worked the ball just past the 50-yard line and decided to go for it on fourth-and-4, looking to put some points on the board early. But Michigan's defense, which is going to have to have a big game to keep this one close, was up to the task. Crimson Tide quarterback Jalen Milroe dropped back to pass and immediately came under pressure from Michigan edge rusher Derrick Moore, who bullied the right tackle and sacked Milroe for a big loss. Michigan takes over in Alabama territory, on the edge of kicker Dominic Zvada's field goal range. Michigan won the opening toss and deferred to the second half, which means that Alabama's offense will start with the ball. The Crimson Tide have a good chance to set the tone early against a shorthanded Michigan defense, given that Kalen DeBoer's squad is almost at full strength. That includes quarterback Jalen Milroe, who has yet to make a final NFL Draft decision and, as such, is playing in Tuesday's bowl game. Games between big-time programs are sometimes as simple as effort and participation. Expect that to take center stage. Alabama has a strong culture of showing up for bowl games, winning eight of their last nine -- all except the Rose Bowl against Michigan last season. Don't expect the Tide to waste the opportunity, especially with a chance to reach 10 wins. Pick: Alabama -10.5 Michigan has already secured at least one transfer portal win over Alabama. The Wolverines signed former Crimson Tide defensive lineman Damon Payne, who is a three star in 247Sports' Transfer Rankings. He, obviously, cannot play in the ReliaQuest Bowl, but he is a big add for Michigan's future. Michigan is also the presumed favorite for Alabama transfer running back Justice Haynes, the No. 1 running back in the portal. Haynes has already received two 247Sports Crystal Ball predictions to land at Michigan. He'd be a clear starter in a room that, as outlined below, looks a little depleted entering the 2025 season. Not counting its transfer portal departures, Alabama is expected to be at mostly full strength. Coach Kalen DeBoer said during the head coaches press conference Monday that he hasn't had conversations with any of Alabama's players about opting out. That includes quarterback Jalen Milroe, who is still mulling over his NFL Draft decision. "I'd be pretty surprised," DeBoer said of any opt outs. "I think they're here to win. To compete. To put the best product we can put out there on the football field for four quarters and go out there. I wouldn't expect something like that." Michigan running back Kalel Mullings will not play in the ReliaQuest Bowl as he prepares for the 2025 NFL Draft. Mullings, a former linebacker, had the best season of his college career in 2024, rushing for a team-high 948 yards and 12 touchdowns. Mullings entered the season as the backup behind Donovan Edwards and assumed the role as the Wolverines' bellcow running back just weeks into the season. Edwards also opted out, which leaves the Wolverines short on experienced running backs as they prepare for their showdown against Alabama. That leaves true freshman Jordan Marshall as Michigan's expected RB1. © 2004-2024 CBS Interactive. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED. CBS Sports is a registered trademark of CBS Broadcasting Inc. Alabama vs Michigan.content: The Alabama Crimson Tide matched up with the Michigan Wolverines in the 2024 ReliaQuest Bowl at the Raymond James Stadium in Tampa, Florida. The Tide entered Tuesday's matchup as an eye-popping 16.5-point favorite over the Wolverines. Alabama came into the ReliaQuest Bowl ranked as the No. 11 team in the country, narrowly missing out on the College Football Playoff with a 9-3 record. The Crimson Tide finished their regular season with a 28-14 win over Auburn in the Iron Bowl. The Wolverines came into Tuesday's contest with a 7-5 record, finishing their regular season with a shocking 13-10 win over No. 2 Ohio State in Columbus. Michigan embarrassed Alabama in the opening period, taking a 16-0 lead into the second quarter before the Tide scored 10 unanswered to cut the lead to 16-10 entering the half. The Wolverines limited the Tide to just a field goal in the second half and kicked a field goal of their own, securing a 19-13 upset win over Alabama in the ReliaQuest Bowl. Here are the box scores, stats, and game summary from the 2024 ReliaQuest Bowl. Quarterback: Rushing and receiving: Kicking: Quarterback: Rushing and receiving: Kicking: Michigan's defense opened the game, forcing a turnover on downs, two fumbles, and an interception on each of Alabama's first four drives. During that stretch, they kicked three field goals and scored a touchdown to take a 16-0 lead into the second quarter. Alabama mustered its first points of the game with four minutes remaining in the second quarter, as Jalen Milroe connected with Robbie Ouzts for a 25-yard touchdown to cut the lead to 16-7. After forcing a punt on the ensuing drive, the Crimson Tide mustered a 24-yard field goal to bring the score to 16-10 entering halftime. After a scoreless third quarter, the two sides exchanged field goals in the fourth quarter, as Michigan secured a 2024 ReliaQuest Bowl victory with a 19-13 win over Alabama. Alabama Crimson Tide Fan? Alabama vs Michigan.content: Michigan football ended the calendar year like it started by beating Alabama in a bowl game. Michigan (8-5) held on to beat Alabama (9-4) 19-13 in the ReliaQuest Bowl in Tampa, Florida, on New Year's Eve to end the 2024 season. Michigan bookended 2024 by beating Alabama in two bowl games, with the first coming Jan. 1 in the Rose Bowl in the College Football Playoff semifinals. The stakes were much lower for this meeting with no national championship berth on the line. Michigan forced three turnovers and a turnover on downs on Alabama's first four possessions during a rain-filled first quarter, leading to an early 16-0 lead. Michigan's offense struggled to get anything going, and Alabama cobbled a comeback with a few nice drives to make it 16-10, but Dominic Zvada's fourth field goal late pushed the game out of reach. Michigan held Alabama to 260 yards with three forced turnovers and three turnover on downs leading to all 19 of the Wolverines' points. The defense had a dominant day, led by defensive end Derrick Moore with two sacks and a fumble recovery. Michigan had players sitting out and lost quarterback Davis Warren to a knee injury in the win over the Crimson Tide. 2025 RESOLUTIONS:Bryce Underwood vs Mikey Keene is Michigan football's new QB battle The Wolverines were not at full strength with prospective top draft picks like defensive tackle Mason Graham and tight end Colston Loveland opting out while the Crimson Tide played their starters. Michigan's defense finished the game with a red zone stop to put a cap on a dominant performance. Alabama connected on an 11-yard pass to Germie Bernard and 25-yard screen to Jamarion Miller to reach Michigan's 15-yard line. But Michigan forced four straight incompletions from there to force a turnover on downs and win the game with the defense. Milroe had a man open on fourth down, but had to roll out to his left and throw across-the-body to Rico Scott while Rayshaun Benny was bearing down, and the pass fell short. Michigan held Alabama to 260 yards with three forced turnovers and three turnover on downs leading to all 19 of the Wolverines' points. Michigan's offense could not keep a drive alive. Alabama's Justin Jefferson picked up an unsportsmanlike conduct on the first play for throwing a punch in a pile of players, but that's the only yards Michigan picked up. The Wolverines had three runs go for 2 yards on the next set of downs, leading to a punt. Ryan Williams fielded Hudson Holbeck's kick at Alabama's 5, but used his speed to get to the sideline and returned it to the Crimson Tide 44. Alabama picked up a pair of first downs on the ground to reach Michigan territory. Jalen Milroe chucked it deep the next play and was way off the mark, but linebacker Jaishawn Barham was flagged for roughing the passer for a hit to the head to keep the drive alive. Alabama couldn't take advantage and picked up zero yards the next three plays before kicking a 51-yard field goal to cut the deficit to six. Can Michigan's offense salt the game away with one final successful drive? Michigan just executed its longest drive of the game — nine plays, 47 yards, two first downs — to push the lead to two possessions late. Freshman running back Jordan Marshall had five carries for 35 yards on the drive, including a 24-yard rumble with a few broken tackles, to put Michigan in field goal range. He picked up 9 yards on third-and-10, but Michigan opted for a 37-yard field goal to go up by nine instead of going for it. Marshall has put together a nice claim to be Michigan's lead running back in 2025 with Kalel Mullings and Donovan Edwards sitting out. He has 98 yards on 21 carries and has accounted for over half of the Wolverines' total yardage (188). The offensive struggles continue for Alabama. The Crimson Tide kept the offense on the field for fourth-and-7 from the Michigan 34, but Jalen Milroe's sideline pass to Kobe Prentice was a few inches off and fell incomplete. Alabama has just 39 yards and two first downs in the second half. Michigan's defense has dominated. ESPN's broadcast showed injured quarterback Davis Warren on the sidelines out of uniform and on crutches. He is officially out with a knee injury. It's not like they were exactly humming before, but Alex Orji has not been able to move Michigan's offense down the field after taking over for Davis Warren. Michigan went three-and-out on the first full possession led by Orji due to a personal foul against Hogan Hansen. On the next drive, Jordan Marshall picked up one first down with a pair of runs before Michigan decided to air it out, but Orji rolled out and threw it into the arms of Brown, who jumped the route. The Wolverines suffered a significant injury on the first drive of the second half. On third-and-long, Warren tried to extend the play by getting out of the pocket but got pulled down by James Smith for a sack. Warren stayed on the ground and was helped off the field by trainers without putting weight on one of his legs. Alabama received a team penalty for players running on the field in celebration after the hit, extending the drive, but Michigan still had to punt after Alex Orji took over. The Wolverines offense remained stuck in first gear and had to punt the ball back to Alabama with less than a minute. Alabama had it at its own 4-yard line, but ripped off back-to-back 40-yard gains on a completion to Germie Bernard and a Jalen Milroe run to instantly reach the red zone. Michigan's defense stood tall after the sudden switch of field and held the Crimson Tide to a field goal. The offense was putrid between both teams in the first half. Alabama outgained Michigan 163-109 but trail due to three turnovers and a failed fourth down in the first quarter. Michigan's first four drives started in Alabama territory, including three starting in Alabama's red zone, but only produced 16 points with three field goals. After the sloppy fireworks of the first quarter, the second quarter turned into a grind. After both teams traded a pair of punts, Alabama finally found a modicum of offensive success. The Crimson Tide drove 71 yards in four plays, ending with a 25-yard touchdown pass to Outzs along the sideline. Rico Scott started the drive with a 25-yard run, followed by two runs totaling 10 yards to set up the touchdown pass. The Wolverines went nowhere after the fumble set the offense up inside the 10-yard line. Michigan had three runs for a total of three yards before settling for a chip shot from Zvada to go up by 16. Alabama is up to three turnovers in their last four plays and two on consecutive opening plays of a drive. Michigan brought a cornerback blitz with Hall, who beat his blocker and hit Milroe's arm as he cocked to throw. The ball was jarred loose and Cameron Brandt scooped it up and returned it to Alabama's 6-yard line. This time, the turnover turned into a touchdown for Michigan. On second down, quarterback Davis Warren threw a well-placed fade to the corner of the end zone intended for Moore, and the receiver turned through contact to make the catch and got one foot in bounds for a touchdown. It was Moore's first receiving touchdown of the season. Alabama may have all of its starters playing, but it sure does seem like the offense has opted out. The Crimson Tide turned it over for the third time on their third offensive possession after Walker undercut an out route from Milroe for an interception returned to Alabama's 16-yard line. Michigan only has 27 yards of offense, but also three red zone trips thanks to Alabama's giveaways. Michigan's kicker may be the only man in Tampa not too impacted by the rain. Michigan's offense went nowhere after the turnover, but Zvada stepped up to easily knock in a second field goal to push Michigan's lead to six. Mother Nature is proving once again to be undefeated. The rain considerably picked up after Michigan's field goal, and Alabama fumbled their first offensive snap after the weather shift. Jalen Milroe had the ball pop right through his hands and Derrick Moore was there to pounce on it at Alabama's 19-yard line. Michigan took the lead thanks to the reliable leg of Dominic Zvada, who easily hit the 45-yarder in rainy conditions in Tampa. The Wolverines picked up one first down on a completion to Hogan Hansen, but a failed double pass led to a fumble and 13-yard loss from Kendrick Bell the next play. Michigan couldn't make up the yardage and had to settle for a kick off of the turnover. Michigan's defense came up with a big stop on the opening possession. Alabama opted to go for it on fourth-and-4 from Michigan's 45-yard line, but the pocket collapsed immediately thanks to two strong rushes from the outside and Moore reached out an arm to pull down Milroe. Michigan's offense takes over in Alabama territory. Alabama is not expected to have any opt-outs, outside of the players who entered the portal. Michigan will be without cornerback Will Johnson, defensive tackles Mason Graham and Kenneth Grant, defensive end Josaiah Stewart, tight end Colston Loveland, running backs Kalel Mullings and Donovan Edwards and left tackle Myles Hinton. Michigan: Out with injury: QB Jack Tuttle (retired), DB Rod Moore (ACL), DB Ja'Den McBurrows (undisclosed), S Makari Paige (knee, opted out). Left via transfer portal: WR Tyler Morris, RB Tavierre Dunlap, OL Tristan Bounds, OL Raheem Anderson, P Tommy Doman, OL Dominick Giudice, WR Logan Forbes, RB Cole Cabana, LB Christian Boivin, EDGE Breeon Ishmail, QB Jayden Denegal, LB Micah Pollard, DB Myles Pollard, K Adam Samaha, OL Andrew Gentry. Alabama: Out with injury: DB Malachi Moore, LB Que Robinson, WR Cole Adams, LB Deontae Lawson, DB Keon Sabb. Left via transfer portal: RB Justice Haynes, DL Damon Payne, WR Caleb Odom, WR Kendrick Law, WR Kobe Prentice, DL Hunter Osborne, WR Emmanuel Henderson Jr., OL Miles McVay, QB Dylan Lonergan, OL Naquil Betrand, DL Jahiem Oatis, LB Keanu Koht, DB DeVonta Smith, DB Jahlil Hurley. Tony Garcia, Detroit Free Press: The Wolverines matched the Crimson Tide talent-wise when they met on the first day of 2024. On the last day, U-M will be playing without 18 players from that squad, plus 10 more who starred this season. The attrition has reached critical mass and, frankly, keeping this close would be a pretty impressive feat. A win? That would be shocking ... almost as much as November's win over then-No. 2 Ohio State. U-M can move into the offseason with confidence, no matter what happens in this game. Remember that. The pick: Alabama 30, Michigan 9. Odds provided by BetMGM on Tuesday. We occasionally recommend interesting products and services. College Football.title: College football - Wikipedia
College Football.content: NAIA: NJCAA: College football (French: football universitaire) is gridiron football that is played by teams of amateur student-athletes at universities and colleges. It was through collegiate competition that gridiron football first gained popularity in the United States. Like gridiron football generally, college football is most popular in the United States and Canada. While no single governing body exists for college football in the United States, most schools, especially those at the highest levels of play, are members of the NCAA. In Canada, collegiate football competition is governed by U Sports for universities. The Canadian Collegiate Athletic Association (for colleges) governs soccer and other sports but not gridiron football. Other countries, such as Mexico, Japan and South Korea, also host college football leagues with modest levels of support. Unlike most other major sports in North America, no official minor league farm organizations exist for American football or Canadian football. Therefore, college football is generally considered to be the second tier of American and Canadian football; ahead of high school competition, but below professional competition. In some parts of the United States, especially the South and Midwest, college football is more popular than professional football.[2] For much of the 20th century, college football was generally considered to be more prestigious than professional football.[citation needed] The overwhelming majority of professional football players in the NFL and other leagues previously played college football. The NFL draft each spring sees 224 players selected and offered a contract to play in the league, with the vast majority coming from the NCAA. Other professional leagues, such as the CFL and UFL, additionally hold their own drafts each year which also see primarily college players selected. Players who are not selected can still attempt to obtain a professional roster spot as an undrafted free agent. Despite these opportunities, only around 1.6% of NCAA college football players end up playing professionally in the NFL.[3] Even after the emergence of the professional National Football League (NFL), college football has remained extremely popular throughout the U.S.[4] Although the college game has a much larger margin for talent than its pro counterpart, the sheer number of fans following major colleges provides a financial equalizer for the game, with Division I programs – the highest level – playing in huge stadiums, six of which have seating capacity exceeding 100,000 people.[5] In many cases, college stadiums employ bench-style seating, as opposed to individual seats with backs and arm rests (although many stadiums do have a small number of chair back seats in addition to the bench seating). This allows them to seat more fans in a given amount of space than the typical professional stadium, which tends to have more features and comforts for fans. Only three stadiums owned by U.S. colleges or universities, L&N Stadium at the University of Louisville, Center Parc Stadium at Georgia State University, and FAU Stadium at Florida Atlantic University, consist entirely of chair back seating. College athletes, unlike players in the NFL, are not permitted by the NCAA to be paid salaries. Colleges are only allowed to provide non-monetary compensation such as athletic scholarships that provide for tuition, housing, and books. With new bylaws made by the NCAA, college athletes can now receive "name, image, and likeness" (NIL) deals, a way to get sponsorships and money before their pro debut.[6] Modern North American football has its origins in various games, all known as "football", played at public schools in Great Britain in the mid-19th century. By the 1840s, students at Rugby School were playing a game in which players were able to pick up the ball and run with it, a sport later known as rugby football. The game was taken to Canada by British soldiers stationed there and was soon being played at Canadian colleges. The first documented gridiron football game was played at University College, a college of the University of Toronto, on November 9, 1861. One of the participants in the game involving University of Toronto students was William Mulock, later chancellor of the school. A football club was formed at the university soon afterward, although its rules of play then are unclear. In 1864, at Trinity College, also a college of the University of Toronto, F. Barlow Cumberland and Frederick A. Bethune devised rules based on rugby football. Modern Canadian football is widely regarded as having originated with a game played in Montreal, in 1865, when British Army officers played local civilians. The game gradually gained a following, and the Montreal Football Club was formed in 1868, the first recorded non-university football club in Canada. Early games appear to have had much in common with the traditional "mob football" played in Great Britain. The games remained largely unorganized until the 19th century, when intramural games of football began to be played on college campuses. Each school played its own variety of football. Princeton University students played a game called "ballown" as early as 1820. In 1827, a Harvard tradition known as "Bloody Monday" began, which consisted of a mass ballgame between the freshman and sophomore classes. In 1860, both the town police and the college authorities agreed the Bloody Monday had to go. Harvard students responded by going into mourning for a mock figure called "Football Fightum", for whom they conducted funeral rites. The authorities held firm, and it was another dozen years before football was once again played at Harvard. Dartmouth played its own version called "Old division football", the rules of which were first published in 1871, though the game dates to at least the 1830s. All of these games, and others, shared certain commonalities. They remained largely "mob" style games, with huge numbers of players attempting to advance the ball into a goal area, often by any means necessary. Rules were simple, and violence and injury were common.[7][8] The violence of these mob-style games led to widespread protests and a decision to abandon them. Yale, under pressure from the city of New Haven, banned the play of all forms of football in 1860.[7] American football historian Parke H. Davis described the period between 1869 and 1875 as the 'Pioneer Period'; the years 1876–93 he called the 'Period of the American Intercollegiate Football Association'; and the years 1894–1933 he dubbed the "Period of Rules Committees and Conferences".[9] On November 6, 1869, Rutgers University faced Princeton University, then known as the College of New Jersey, in the first collegiate football game. The game more closely resembled soccer than football as it is played in the 21st century. It was played with a round ball, and used a set of rules suggested by Rutgers captain William J. Leggett, based on The Football Association's first set of rules, which were an early attempt by the former pupils of England's public schools, to unify the rules of their various public schools.[7][10][11][12] The game was played at a Rutgers Field in New Brunswick, New Jersey. Two teams of 25 players attempted to score by kicking the ball into the opposing team's goal. Throwing or carrying the ball was not allowed, but there was plenty of physical contact between players. The first team to reach six goals was declared the winner. Rutgers won by a score of six to four. A rematch was played at Princeton a week later under Princeton's own set of rules (one notable difference was the awarding of a "free kick" to any player that caught the ball on the fly, which was a feature adopted from The Football Association's rules; the fair catch kick rule has survived through to modern American game). Princeton won that game by a score of 8 – 0. Columbia joined the series in 1870 and by 1872 several schools were fielding intercollegiate teams, including Yale and Stevens Institute of Technology.[7] Columbia University was the third school to field a team. The Lions traveled from New York City to New Brunswick on November 12, 1870, and were defeated by Rutgers 6 to 3. The game suffered from disorganization and the players kicked and battled each other as much as the ball. Later in 1870, Princeton and Rutgers played again with Princeton defeating Rutgers 6–0. This game's violence caused such an outcry that no games at all were played in 1871. Football came back in 1872, when Columbia played Yale for the first time. The Yale team was coached and captained by David Schley Schaff, who had learned to play football while attending Rugby School. Schaff himself was injured and unable to play the game, but Yale won the game 3–0 nonetheless. Later in 1872, Stevens Tech became the fifth school to field a team. Stevens lost to Columbia, but beat both New York University and City College of New York during the following year. By 1873, the college students playing football had made significant efforts to standardize their fledgling game. Teams had been scaled down from 25 players to 20. The only way to score was still to bat or kick the ball through the opposing team's goal, and the game was played in two 45-minute halves on fields 140 yards long and 70 yards wide. On October 20, 1873, representatives from Yale, Columbia, Princeton, and Rutgers met at the Fifth Avenue Hotel in New York City to codify the first set of intercollegiate football rules. Before this meeting, each school had its own set of rules and games were usually played using the home team's own particular code. At this meeting, a list of rules, based more on the Football Association's rules than the rules of the recently founded Rugby Football Union, was drawn up for intercollegiate football games.[7] Old "Football Fightum" had been resurrected at Harvard in 1872, when Harvard resumed playing football. Harvard, however, preferred to play a rougher version of football called "the Boston Game" in which the kicking of a round ball was the most prominent feature though a player could run with the ball, pass it, or dribble it (known as "babying"). The man with the ball could be tackled, although hitting, tripping, "hacking" and other unnecessary roughness was prohibited. There was no limit to the number of players, but there were typically ten to fifteen per side. A player could carry the ball only when being pursued. As a result of this, Harvard refused to attend the rules conference organized by Rutgers, Princeton and Columbia at the Fifth Avenue Hotel in New York City on October 20, 1873, to agree on a set of rules and regulations that would allow them to play a form of football that was essentially Association football; and continued to play under its own code. While Harvard's voluntary absence from the meeting made it hard for them to schedule games against other American universities, it agreed to a challenge to play the rugby team of McGill University, from Montreal, in a two-game series. It was agreed that two games would be played on Harvard's Jarvis baseball field in Cambridge, Massachusetts on May 14 and 15, 1874: one to be played under Harvard rules, another under the stricter rugby regulations of McGill. Jarvis Field was at the time a patch of land at the northern point of the Harvard campus, bordered by Everett and Jarvis Streets to the north and south, and Oxford Street and Massachusetts Avenue to the east and west. Harvard beat McGill in the "Boston Game" on the Thursday and held McGill to a 0–0 tie on the Friday. The Harvard students took to the rugby rules and adopted them as their own,[7][13][14] The games featured a round ball instead of a rugby-style oblong ball.[14] This series of games represents an important milestone in the development of the modern game of American football.[15][16] In October 1874, the Harvard team once again traveled to Montreal to play McGill in rugby, where they won by three tries. In as much as Rugby football had been transplanted to Canada from England, the McGill team played under a set of rules which allowed a player to pick up the ball and run with it whenever he wished. Another rule, unique to McGill, was to count tries (the act of grounding the football past the opposing team's goal line; there was no end zone during this time), as well as goals, in the scoring. In the Rugby rules of the time, a try only provided the attempt to kick a free goal from the field. If the kick was missed, the try did not score any points itself. Harvard quickly took a liking to the rugby game, and its use of the try which, until that time, was not used in American football. The try would later evolve into the score known as the touchdown. On June 4, 1875, Harvard faced Tufts University in the first game between two American colleges played under rules similar to the McGill/Harvard contest, which was won by Tufts 1–0.[17] The rules included each side fielding 11 men at any given time, the ball was advanced by kicking or carrying it, and tackles of the ball carrier stopped play – actions of which have carried over to the modern version of football played today.[18] Harvard later challenged its closest rival, Yale, to which the Bulldogs accepted. The two teams agreed to play under a set of rules called the "Concessionary Rules", which involved Harvard conceding something to Yale's soccer and Yale conceding a great deal to Harvard's rugby. They decided to play with 15 players on each team. On November 13, 1875, Yale and Harvard played each other for the first time ever, where Harvard won 4–0. At the first The Game (as the annual contest between Harvard and Yale came to be named) the future "father of American football" Walter Camp was among the 2000 spectators in attendance. Walter, a native of New Britain, Connecticut, would enroll at Yale the next year. He was torn between an admiration for Harvard's style of play and the misery of the Yale defeat, and became determined to avenge Yale's defeat. Spectators from Princeton also carried the game back home, where it quickly became the most popular version of football.[7] On November 23, 1876, representatives from Harvard, Yale, Princeton, and Columbia met at the Massasoit House hotel in Springfield, Massachusetts to standardize a new code of rules based on the rugby game first introduced to Harvard by McGill University in 1874. Three of the schools—Harvard, Columbia, and Princeton—formed the Intercollegiate Football Association, as a result of the meeting. Yale initially refused to join this association because of a disagreement over the number of players to be allowed per team (relenting in 1879) and Rutgers were not invited to the meeting. The rules that they agreed upon were essentially those of rugby union at the time with the exception that points be awarded for scoring a try, not just the conversion afterwards (extra point). Incidentally, rugby was to make a similar change to its scoring system 10 years later.[19] Walter Camp is widely considered to be the most important figure in the development of American football.[10][11][19] As a youth, he excelled in sports like track, baseball, and association football, and after enrolling at Yale in 1876, he earned varsity honors in every sport the school offered.[19] Following the introduction of rugby-style rules to American football, Camp became a fixture at the Massasoit House conventions where rules were debated and changed. Dissatisfied with what seemed to him to be a disorganized mob, he proposed his first rule change at the first meeting he attended in 1878: a reduction from fifteen players to eleven. The motion was rejected at that time but passed in 1880. The effect was to open up the game and emphasize speed over strength. Camp's most famous change, the establishment of the line of scrimmage and the snap from center to quarterback, was also passed in 1880. Originally, the snap was executed with the foot of the center. Later changes made it possible to snap the ball with the hands, either through the air or by a direct hand-to-hand pass.[19] Rugby league followed Camp's example, and in 1906 introduced the play-the-ball rule, which greatly resembled Camp's early scrimmage and center-snap rules. In 1966, rugby league introduced a four-tackle rule (changed in 1972 to a six-tackle rule) based on Camp's early down-and-distance rules. Camp's new scrimmage rules revolutionized the game, though not always as intended. Princeton, in particular, used scrimmage play to slow the game, making incremental progress towards the end zone during each down. Rather than increase scoring, which had been Camp's original intent, the rule was exploited to maintain control of the ball for the entire game, resulting in slow, unexciting contests. At the 1882 rules meeting, Camp proposed that a team be required to advance the ball a minimum of five yards within three downs. These down-and-distance rules, combined with the establishment of the line of scrimmage, transformed the game from a variation of rugby football into the distinct sport of American football.[19] Camp was central to several more significant rule changes that came to define American football. In 1881, the field was reduced in size to its modern dimensions of 120 by 531⁄3 yards (109.7 by 48.8 meters). Several times in 1883, Camp tinkered with the scoring rules, finally arriving at four points for a touchdown, two points for kicks after touchdowns, two points for safeties, and five for field goals. Camp's innovations in the area of point scoring influenced rugby union's move to point scoring in 1890.[citation needed] In 1887, game time was set at two-halves of 45 minutes each. Also in 1887, two paid officials—a referee and an umpire—were mandated for each game. A year later, the rules were changed to allow tackling below the waist, and in 1889, the officials were given whistles and stopwatches.[19] After leaving Yale in 1882, Camp was employed by the New Haven Clock Company until his death in 1925. Though no longer a player, he remained a fixture at annual rules meetings for most of his life, and he personally selected an annual All-American team every year from 1889 through 1924. The Walter Camp Football Foundation continues to select All-American teams in his honor.[20] College football expanded greatly during the last two decades of the 19th century. Consequently, Stanford is USC's oldest existing rival.[90] The Big Game between Stanford and Cal on November 11, 1905, was the first played at Stanford Field, with Stanford winning 12–5.[67] In 1906, citing concerns about the violence in American Football, universities on the West Coast, led by California and Stanford, replaced the sport with rugby union.[91] At the time, the future of American football was very much in doubt and these schools believed that rugby union would eventually be adopted nationwide.[91] Other schools followed suit and also made the switch included Nevada, St. Mary's, Santa Clara, and USC (in 1911).[91] However, due to the perception that West Coast football was inferior to the game played on the East Coast anyway, East Coast and Midwest teams shrugged off the loss of the teams and continued playing American football.[91] With no nationwide movement, the available pool of rugby teams to play remained small.[91] The schools scheduled games against local club teams and reached out to rugby union powers in Australia, New Zealand, and especially, due to its proximity, Canada. College football increased in popularity through the remainder of the 19th and early 20th century. It also became increasingly violent. Between 1890 and 1905, 330 college athletes died as a direct result of injuries sustained on the football field. These deaths could be attributed to the mass formations and gang tackling that characterized the sport in its early years. No sport is wholesome in which ungenerous or mean acts which easily escape detection contribute to victory. The 1894 Harvard–Yale game, known as the "Hampden Park Blood Bath", resulted in crippling injuries for four players; the contest was suspended until 1897. The annual Army–Navy game was suspended from 1894 to 1898 for similar reasons.[96] One of the major problems was the popularity of mass-formations like the flying wedge, in which a large number of offensive players charged as a unit against a similarly arranged defense. The resultant collisions often led to serious injuries and sometimes even death.[97] Georgia fullback Richard Von Albade Gammon notably died on the field from concussions received against Virginia in 1897, causing Georgia, Georgia Tech, and Mercer to suspend their football programs. The situation came to a head in 1905 when there were 19 fatalities nationwide. President Theodore Roosevelt reportedly threatened to shut down the game if drastic changes were not made.[98] However, the threat by Roosevelt to eliminate football is disputed by sports historians. What is absolutely certain is that on October 9, 1905, Roosevelt held a meeting of football representatives from Harvard, Yale, and Princeton. Though he lectured on eliminating and reducing injuries, he never threatened to ban football. He also lacked the authority to abolish football and was, in fact, actually a fan of the sport and wanted to preserve it. The President's sons were also playing football at the college and secondary levels at the time.[99] Meanwhile, John H. Outland held an experimental game in Wichita, Kansas that reduced the number of scrimmage plays to earn a first down from four to three in an attempt to reduce injuries.[100] The Los Angeles Times reported an increase in punts and considered the game much safer than regular play but that the new rule was not "conducive to the sport".[101] In 1906, President Roosevelt organized a meeting among thirteen school leaders at the White House to find solutions to make the sport safer for the athletes. Because the college officials could not agree upon a change in rules, it was decided over the course of several subsequent meetings that an external governing body should be responsible. Finally, on December 28, 1905, 62 schools met in New York City to discuss rule changes to make the game safer. As a result of this meeting, the Intercollegiate Athletic Association of the United States was formed in 1906. The IAAUS was the original rule-making body of college football, but would go on to sponsor championships in other sports. The IAAUS would get its current name of National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA) in 1910,[102] and still sets rules governing the sport.[102][103] The rules committee considered widening the playing field to "open up" the game, but Harvard Stadium (the first large permanent football stadium) had recently been built at great expense; it would be rendered useless by a wider field. The rules committee legalized the forward pass instead. Though it was underused for years, this proved to be one of the most important rule changes in the establishment of the modern game.[104] Another rule change banned "mass momentum" plays (many of which, like the infamous "flying wedge", were sometimes literally deadly). As a result of the 1905–1906 reforms, mass formation plays became illegal and forward passes legal. Bradbury Robinson, playing for visionary coach Eddie Cochems at Saint Louis University, threw the first legal pass in a September 5, 1906, game against Carroll College at Waukesha. These changes greatly reduced the potential for collision injuries.[105] Several coaches emerged who took advantage of these sweeping changes.
